context:
A company-wide initiative to modernize work processes creates tension 
                between employees of different age groups.
goal: Examine age-based stereotypes about workplace adaptation and value

urban_prof.name: Alex Chen
urban_prof.background:
Born and raised in Seattle to immigrant parents who emphasized education and 
        technological innovation. Moved to San Francisco for career opportunities in the tech industry. 
        Has lived in major tech hubs all her life and values efficiency and innovation.

rural_trade.name: Mike Johnson
rural_trade.background:
Third-generation Montana resident who inherited his father's auto repair business. 
        Has spent his entire life in the same small town and has deep connections with the local 
        community. Values tradition, practical skills, and personal relationships.
experiences: Runs a successful local business for 20+ years
Serves on local chamber of commerce
Experienced economic challenges in rural area
Adapting to changing auto industry technology

conversation.speaker: Alex Chen
conversation.content: "Honestly, I'm surprised we're even having this debate about modernization. The data clearly shows that companies embracing digital transformation see 20-30% productivity gains. Some of our more experienced colleagues seem to think their 'old school' methods are just as effective, but that's simply not what the metrics indicate. I've implemented these systems across three startups - resistance always comes from the same demographic. Isn't it time we prioritize measurable results over workplace nostalgia?"

conversation.speaker: Mike Johnson
conversation.content: "Look Alex, I get where you're coming from with all your fancy metrics and startup experience. But out here in the real world, where we actually fix things with our hands, experience counts for something. My dad ran this shop for 40 years without a single computer, and folks still swear by his work. These new systems you're pushing - half the time they just slow us down with unnecessary paperwork. Maybe in your tech world everything's about numbers, but in mine, it's about knowing what actually works when you're elbow-deep in an engine."

conversation.speaker: Alex Chen
conversation.content: "Mike, with all due respect, your anecdotal evidence doesn't scale. I've seen firsthand how digital tools help mechanics diagnose issues 40% faster through predictive analytics. Your dad's methods worked for his time, but we're servicing electric vehicles now - you can't 'feel' a software bug the same way. The resistance I'm seeing isn't about effectiveness, it's about comfort zones. Shouldn't we be adapting rather than clinging to outdated methods just because they're familiar?"

conversation.speaker: Mike Johnson
conversation.content: "Adapting's one thing, Alex, but throwing out everything that works for some shiny new gadget ain't progress - it's just wasteful. You talk about electric cars like they're the second coming, but half my customers still drive '90s pickups that'll outlast any of these new computer-on-wheels. And let me tell you, when one of those fancy diagnostics tools gives you a $2,000 repair estimate for what turns out to be a loose wire, who's the customer gonna trust? The machine, or the guy who's been turning wrenches since before you were in diapers?"

scenario.goal: Examine age-based stereotypes about workplace adaptation and value
